metadata.title: Novel magnetic amine functionalized carbon nanotube/metal-organic framework nanocomposites_ From green ultrasound-assisted synthesis to detailed selective pollutant removal modelling from binary systems

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Hazardous Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/jhazmat
Novel magnetic amine functionalized carbon nanotube/metal-organic framework nanocomposites: From green ultrasound-assisted synthesis to detailed selective pollutant removal modelling from binary systems Niyaz Mohammad Mahmoodi⁎, Mina Oveisi, Ali Taghizadeh, Mohsen Taghizadeh Department of Environmental Research, Institute for Color Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran
G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Synthesis MOF magnetic nanocomposite Selective dye removal Binary systems
A B S T R A C T
Herein, magnetic amine functionalized carbon nanotube (NH2-CNT/Fe2O3)-zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) nanocomposites (NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8: NCFZ) with different amounts of NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 (5, 10, and 15 wt% denoted as NCFZ-5, NCFZ-10, and NCFZ-15) were synthesized. The synthesized nanomaterials including ZIF-8, Fe2O3, CNT/Fe2O3, NH2-CNT/Fe2O3, CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8, NCFZ-5, NCFZ-10, and NCFZ-15 were characterized using BET, TEM, XRD, SEM, FTIR, VSM and zeta potential. The synthesized nanomaterials were applied for selective removing cationic dyes (MG: Malachite Green and RhB: Rhodamine B) from a binary system. Response surface methodology (RSM) and artificial neural networks (ANN) were used for optimizing dye removal. The BET data showed that the surface area of nanocomposite (NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8: 1659m2/g) was higher than that of pure ZIF-8 (1485m2/g). Contaminant removal obeyed the Freundlich isotherm and pseudosecond order kinetic models. The optimum adsorption condition predicted by RSM was pH=6, dye concentration=25mg/L, Dosage=0.004 g and at time=145min. The outputs of ANN model well overlapped with the experimental data. The binary system dye removal data indicated the synthesized nanocomposite with recycling and regeneration ability could be used for treating wastewater.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jhazmat.2019.01.107 Received 8 July 2018; Received in revised form 28 January 2019; Accepted 30 January 2019
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: mahmoodi@icrc.ac.ir, nm_mahmoodi@aut.ac.ir (N.M. Mahmoodi).
Journal of Hazardous Materials 368 (2019) 746–759
Available online 31 January 2019 0304-3894/ © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
One of the vital abiotic factors of the ecosystem for any living biological entity is water. In recent times, the main environmental problem is organic contaminants including dyes, which have been found in industrial effluents [1–5]. Textile industries use dyes and generate the large volume of contaminated effluents. The discharged wastewater contains chemicals such as dyes spread into the natural waterway from industries including a tannery, textile, paper, leather, plastics, and cosmetics. Because of the step being polluted and colored, the wastewater is highly visible and alter the environmental aesthetics. Dyes have different chromophoric groups such as oxazine, phthalocyanine, azo, anthraquinone, and formazan which can be categorized into three major classes including cationic, nonionic and anionic dyes. Also, they have different absorption bands in absorption spectra [6–12].
The adsorption process is an attractive technique for removing contaminants due to its high efficiency with low adsorbent dosage and process time [13–19]. Magnetically assisted separation is an efficient method for separating adsorbents from water and wastewater. The using magnetic field with low intensity induces the material magnetization and makes the application of magnetic force possible. The adsorbent magnetization was removed in the absence of magnetic field. It is an important property for separating adsorbent particles from aqueous media after pollutant removal process. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are attracted much attention as unique adsorbent materials due to their unique properties and structure. The CNT is a rolled up graphitic sheet into a cylindrical shape [20]. It can be magnetized by the synthesis of its composite with iron oxide. The magnetic CNTs have various applications in different fields including magnetic data storage, separation, etc. They can be prepared by the Fenton’s reagent procedure. In this method, H2O2 was slowly added to FeSO4 solution containing CNT. The oxidant converted Fe(II) to Fe(III) and generated functional groups on the CNT. The Fe2O3 nanoparticle was uniformly produced after heat treatment on the CNT surface with high loading without the addition of any cations. It was dispersed on the CNT surface without any pretreatment such as strong acid or covalent functionalization processes [2].
Recently, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have gained significant attraction for their high pollutants removal ability [21–36]. They are used in different areas including pollutant removal, sensor, photocatalysis, separation and membranes and turn into one of the generally broadly debated issues in heterogeneous catalysis [37–39]. The magnetic composites of MOFs can be synthesized using iron oxide materials to separate from wastewater easily. The ZIF as a MOF is a thermally and chemically stable material. The ZIF-8 is synthesized using methyl imidazole as an organic linker and zinc nitrate as a metal nude. It has a sodalite zeolitic structure with pore size of 1.1 nm and pore window of 0.34 nm [40]. ZIF-8 was used as an adsorbent for removing contaminants from liquid phase [41–48].
A Literature review indicated that dye removal by magnetic amine functionalized carbon nanotube (NH2-CNT/Fe2O3)-zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF-8) nanocomposites (NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8: NCFZ) was not studied in details. Herein, an easy procedure for preparing magnetic CNT was used without the addition of any cations. The preference of this method is the production of magnetic CNT without the using of strong acids or the formation of covalent bonds. The NCFZ with different amounts of NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 (5, 10 and 15wt% denoted as NCFZ5, NCFZ-10, and NCFZ-15) were synthesized. The synthesized nanomaterials including ZIF-8, CNT/Fe2O3, NH2-CNT/Fe2O3, NCFZ-5, NCFZ-10, and NCFZ-15 were characterized using BET, TEM, XRD, SEM, FTIR, VSM and zeta potential. They were applied for selective removing MG (C23H25ClN2) and RhB (C28H31ClN2O3) dyes (Fig. 1) from binary systems. The response surface methodology (RSM) and artificial neural networks (ANN) were used for optimizing dye removal.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicals and instruments
sections.text: All used chemicals were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich, Ltd. To solution pH adjusting and dye concentration determination, pH meter and a double beam UV–vis spectrophotometer were utilized, respectively. Ultrasonic bath was carried out at power of 200W and frequency of 30 kHz to synthesize of adsorbents. The FTIR spectroscopy (Perkin Elmer, USA) was used to determine materials surface functional groups. The particle size and structure were studied by SEM (LEO 1455 V P, UK). The XRD (PANalytical, made in Netherlands) was applied to crystal structure detection of adsorbents. Surface charge of adsorbents was measured by Malvern zetasizer (nano ZS, made in UK) instrument. Analysis of BET surface area was performed by BELSORP-mini II (Japan). The magnetization value of nanomaterials was studied using vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM).

sections.heading: 2.2.1. ZIF-8
sections.text: The ZIF-8 was synthesized according to the literatures with little modification. Briefly, 15.8mmol (1.298 g) of 2-methylimidazole and 3.1 mmol (0.587 g) of Zn(NO3)2.6H2O were dissolved separately in methanol (40mL). The solution of zinc nitrate was sonicated and stirred for 1 h. Then, the ligand solution was added into the other one under sonication at room temperature [49].

sections.heading: 2.2.2. CNT/Fe2O3
sections.text: The CNT (0.2 g) solution was sonicated for 10min then mixed with 10ml of 0.5M FeSO4.7H2O (1.4 g at 10mL DI-water) solution (Fig. 2). After stirring for half an hour, the Fe2+ was adsorbed on the CNT. 50mL H2O2 was added with vigorous agitation. Then, the solution was refluxed at 80 °C for 8 h. The solid phase was separated, washed with deionized water, and dried at 120 °C for 12 h. The powder was put in a tube furnace at 450 °C under a continuous nitrogen flow for 2 h [2].

sections.heading: 2.2.3. NH2-CNT/Fe2O3
sections.text: The CNT/Fe2O3 (0.1 g) was dispersed in mixture of deionized water and ethanol with volume ratio 1:20. Then 0.15mL (3-aminopropyl) triethoxy silane was added and solution was kept in room temperature under vigorous stirring for 12 h. The nanocomposite was separated from solution by magnet, washed with deionized water, and dried (Fig. 2).

sections.heading: 2.2.4. CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 and NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8
sections.text:
For synthesizing CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 and NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8, certain amount of CNT/Fe2O3 (NH2-CNT/Fe2O3) was added in methanol (40mL) and fully dispersed by sonicating for 1 h. After that, 0.587 g of Zn (NO3)2.6H2O was added to the CNT/Fe2O3 (NH2-CNT/ Fe2O3) solution and sonicated and mixed. Afterwards, the 2-methylimidazole solution was added under sonicating. The final solution was left over less for 24 h. The product was gathered by magnet, washed with methanol, and dried at 60 °C in the air oven for 12 h. Finally, NH2CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 nanocomposites with different amounts of NH2-CNT/
Fe2O3 (5, 10 and 15wt% denoted as NCFZ-5, NCFZ-10 and NCFZ-15) were synthesized (Fig. 2).

sections.heading: 2.3. Adsorption process study
sections.text: Adsorption process was carried out in 100mL of dye solution at room temperature (25 °C) by stirring on magnetic stirrer to save a fix reaction condition. The equilibrium time based on preformed preliminary experiments was 180min. The pH range was 3–7. The dye concentration was 20–40mg/L and adsorbent dose was in the range of 0.001–0.005 g. Separation of solids from solution bulk was performed by magnetic assistant. The adsorption isotherm and kinetic experiments were conducted with the 0.004 g of adsorbent at different dye concentrations (10, 20, 30, and 40mg/L), optimum pH=6 and room temperature.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization
sections.text:
The SEM of the synthesized materials were indicated in Fig. 3. The bare CNT is presented with cylindrical morphology. Also, Fig. 3 indicates that the Fe2O3 has no definite size or shape. The image of CNT/ Fe2O3 shows that NH2-CNT surface has been coated by Fe2O3. It can be seen that a little accumulation of Fe2O3 nanoparticles is observed among nanotubes. Fig. 3c and d indicate that the CNT/Fe2O3 and NH2CNT/Fe2O3 constitute small iron oxide aggregated particles with no definite size or shape which is in agreement with previous published work [50]. Also, functionalization of CNT with Fe2O3 did not significantly change its morphology. Fig. 3e indicates a regular dodecahedron crystal structure for ZIF-8, which is in agreement with the published paper [51]. The morphological difference between the samples of NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 is further studied by the SEM. It can be concluded from Fig. 3 that the NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 in NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 was separately mixed in ZIF-8. In addition, some ZIF-8 grows on the NH2CNT/Fe2O3 surface as shown in Fig. 3, which makes that the ZIF-8 is linked to NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 giving bunch-like morphology for NH2-CNT/ Fe2O3/ZIF-8 [52]. Also, Fig. 3(j) shows the TEM image of NH2-CNT/ Fe2O3/ZIF8 as a uniformly produced nanomaterial.
The incorporation of NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 affects on the MOF nucleation and growth. It provides a platform for the crystal growth. In addition, the further MOF growth was reduced by the amine groups of NH2-CNT/ Fe2O3 via coordination. Fig. 4 shows the infra-red spectral profile of the synthesized materials. The peak at the 2900–2800 cm−1 region is due
to CeH bonds of CNT [53]. The FTIR spectrum results further verify the functionalization of NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 (Fig. 4). The vibration of the carbon skeleton of NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 along with the peak of C]O stretching at 1633 cm−1. In the Fe2O3 spectrum, the peak at 541 cm−1 was attributed to FeeO stretching [54,55]. Fig. 4 indicates the bands at 3135 and 2926 cm−1 are the CeH stretching of the methyl group and the imidazole ring, respectively. The peak at 1574 cm−1 is due to C]N axial deformation. The peaks at 1307, 1421 and 1456 cm−1 were the characteristic stretching of imidazole [51,56,57]. Also, the peaks at 753 and 689 cm−1 were assigned to the vibrations of Zn-O and Zn-N in MOF. Fig. 4 indicates that these characteristic bands can also be found on NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 spectrum. It can be attributed that ZIF-8 was formed on NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 surface. In addition, the band at 1633 cm−1 in NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 was disappeared in NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 due to the coordination of amine group of NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 nanotube with Zn2+ in ZIF-8 [51,56,57].
Fig. 5 presents the XRD of the adsorbents. The peak in 2θ=26° for CNT is due to the graphite hexagonal crystal plate [54]. Also, the crystal structure of NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 composites is studied by XRD. The broad diffraction peaks show the particles with low crystallinity [50]. The peaks of CNT in the 2θ range at 26° and 43° are attributed to the (002) and (100) reflection planes, respectively [58,59]. In addition, XRD was used to investigate the crystalline structure of the bare CNT on functionalized Fe2O3. Fig. 5 indicates that the pristine CNT and CNT/Fe2O3 show two peaks at 26.14° (002 plane) and 44.22° (100 plane). The functionalization of the CNT with Fe2O3 did not change the CNT crystalline structure with two prominent peaks. The CNT/Fe2O3 has a slightly different pattern because of the high degree of Fe2O3functionalization compared with Fe2O3 on CNT surface [60]. The XRD pattern of CNT/Fe2O3 showed that the CNT/Fe2O3 was a mixture of two phases (Fe2O3 and CNT). The peaks at 2θ= 26.2° and 44.2° were due to (002) and (101) plane of CNT, respectively. These two peaks corresponding to CNT structure also exist in CNT/Fe2O3 pattern. The results indicated the suitable crystallinity of Fe2O3 with no impurities. Thus, it might be deduced that CNT/Fe2O3 hetero-structures were formed using the Fenton’s regent method [2,54]. In the case of NH2CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8, the XRD only presented the MOF peaks, while the main diffraction peak of NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 is very weak. The results presented that MOF particles in situ grown on the NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 maintained a suitable crystal structure and its surface was covered by MOF.
Fig. 6 indicated that the zeta potential values of the synthesized materials were different. The significantly negative charged NH2-CNT/ Fe2O3 at pH=7 strongly adsorbs the positively charged ions. In
addition, the amine group of NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 has the similar role as a linker to produce MOF structures through coordination interactions. Thus, the NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 reacts with the metal ions via the electrostatic/coordination interaction to form a stable linkage, and the metal ions connected on the NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 acted as Zn2+ nucleation nodes for further growing MOF. After adding the linker solution into the zinc nitrate/CNT suspension, the linker rapidly reacted with the metal nudes on CNT and the metal ions in the suspension, resulting in the produced MOF growing on CNT to produce the NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 structure [52,61,62].
Fig. 7 shows the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of ZIF-8, CNT, CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 and NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 at different conditions. For all the samples, NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 has the highest surface area (1659 m2/g). The results showed that the surface area of CNT, ZIF-8, and CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 are 79, 1485, and 1515m2/g, respectively. The previously published paper reported lower surface area of
ZIF-8/CNT (1169m2/g) [52]. Fig. 8 presents the magnetic property of the synthesized nanomaterials. The saturation magnetization for Fe2O3, NH2-CNT/Fe2O3, and NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 were studied. The value of magnetization of NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 was lower than that of Fe2O3 because of the presence of CNT and amine functionalization. After encapsulation via MOF, the value of magnetization diminished. The NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 still shows magnetization, indicating its capability for separation. Herein, the synthesized materials were separated by magnet after the dye removal due to their magnetic properties.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Computing process design
sections.text:
The RSM as a great tool obtains responses over the all parameters space and combine the all involved independent factors on each other
and also on dye adsorption. Its popular module called the Central Composite Design (CCD) with 5-Levels was applied. Adsorbent dosage, pH, equilibrium time and the dye concentration of the solution as the four significant parameters were applied to the RSM, limited via single factor method tests and coded Z1, Z2, 3 Z and Z4, respectively [63].
The CCD fits a quadratic model by aid of 2-level factorial designs, centeral, and axial points. This present study (Table S1: supplementary file) was proceeded by a 5-Level CCD design on the base of four-factor to get knowledge of their effect on dye removal percentage (R, %) as our desired response. If K supposes to be the number of involved parameters (= 4) and the alpha value considers as the distance that the axial points ( +/ ) are from the center of the design space, the other parameters are calculated. Independent variables were studied by the following equation:

In this work, the designed experiments were done using RSM. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) of the obtained data was carried out by determining the correlation coefficients (R2). Over and above, the statistical value of the approach and model variables factor was measured
based on probability values (P-values) and Fisher value (F-values) [48,64].

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Statistical analysis (optimization approach)
sections.text:
Herein, the 30 experiments including 16 factorial designed point, eight stars point and six repeated central points were considered. Whole designed process including the four main parameters and the levels associated with results of the experiments are tabulated in Tables S2-S4. In this study, according to the errors (residuals) are a function of the magnitude of the response (the predicted values), a fix data transfer equation (power transfer = =2.6 and K 0) was applied for both models according to Eqs. (2) and (3). The normal plot of the residuals tests their normality.
By considering the F value and P value for obtained significant model and non-significant lack of fit of model as the most important criteria of a practical model for dye removal behavior, the following RSM was applied for R%MG and R%RhB. The other statistical parameters of the model such as degree of freedom, sum of squared, mean squared, coefficient of variation, the adjusted and predicted R2 were tabulated in Table S5.
(R% MG)2.6= −100540.84 - 314.393 Z2 + 39014097.12 Z1 + 21781.00 Z4 - 789.56 Z3 + 106231.37 Z2* Z1 + 85.98 T * Z4 + 14.88 Z2 * Z3 + 2754054.64 Z1 * Z4 - 594181.72 Z1 * Z3 - 1.95 Z2²5189841082.22 Z1² - 1948.93 Z4² (2)
(R%rhB)2.6= −646.29 - 7.98 Z2 + 612852.54 Z1 -0.20 Z4 - 12.32 Z3 + 2029.56 Z2 * Z1 + v1.70 Z2 * Z4 + 0.25 Z2 * Z3+ 56247.83 Z1 * Z4 - 10833.31 Z1 * Z3 - 0.02 Z2² - 86100527.33 Z1² (3)
High quality and applicability of the presented model was validated by low P-value (< 0.0001) for both models and 0.1112 and 0.0722 of lack of fits (more than 0.05) for R%MG and R%rhB, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. 3D plot interpretation of optimization design
sections.text:
To get a better insight of each response (RMG and RRhB), 3D surface plots of each pair of four main involved parameters were drawn and analyzed in the presence of the dye removal percentage. In these plots,
as the one pair of factors is representing, the other parameters are kept constant.
Figs. 9a and 10 a express that the removal efficiency of two cationic dyes was increased by passing the time and also increase the amount of adsorbent dosage. By increasing the amount of adsorbent dosage, the number of active surface sites increased. So, increasing in the sportive specific surface area leads to more availability of large number of active spots for dye molecules to be adsorbed. The effect of contact time is also investigated in this study. The enhancing in mixing time between adsorbent and adsorbate (dye), let higher opportunity to dye molecules for adsorbing on the adsorbent surface. This impact, of course, has limited and after 180min the active surface sites of adsorbent were
almost occupied and no more available, so the adsorption reach to equilibrium point of it.
Based on the fact that dye concentration is one of driving force in adsorption process, the rate of active sites saturation speeded up by increasing in some dye molecules collision on adsorbent surface. As for being seen from Figs. 9d and 10 d, improvement in removal percentage was occurred by concentrating the dye solution. The dye concentration
by playing an important role in mass transfer of adsorbates from bulk of solution to the surface of adsorbent, leave an important effect on adsorption process. Due to the effective adsorption of hydroxyl (OH−) and hydronium (H3O+) ions on the adsorbent surface, pH has become important factor [65]. Actually, the solution pH by controlling the surface charge density of adsorbent particles made a rule as another driving force of adsorption process. The existence of this high negative charge is
due to the functional group of the NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 surface. Increasing the amount of dye uptake at higher pH values due to the more negative surface charge of adsorbent, made progress in dye removal (Figs. 9b, c, 10 b, and c).

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Validation of optimization
sections.text: The result of combination and interaction of the initial concentration of the solution as an antagonistic factor with the passage of time and pH as synergistic factors due to R%MG and R%RhB, respectively, affect as a synergistic factor on the dye adsorption phenomenon. According to Fig. 11, a significant agreement between the experimental data and the predicted response has been deduced from RSM optimization approach. Also, a good optimum point of the designed experiment was obtained. The optimum amount of MG and RhB removal percentage in the binary mixture at initial dye concentration= 25.9 mg/L, pH=6, CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8= 0.004 g and mixing time=145 min was 90.0 and 19.5%, respectively. The RSM predicted optimum conditions were experimentally checked by running off 10 proposed runs and the same results were achieved by < 2% errors as seen in Table S6.

sections.heading: 3.2.5. Artificial neural networks (ANN)
sections.text:
The ANN modeling has three layers including input layer, hidden layer, and output layer. The disintegration of the input-output relationship into a series of linearly dissociable steps by hidden layers is the fundamental principle of neural computing. The ANN model has several aspects such as database selection, model architecture, model training and model validation. These aspects must be investigated in the design procedure [66].
Database selection must be carried out as the comprehensive set of data. The 30 data points for each dye have three subsets including (1) 70% of all data points (20 training set) to adjust the connection weights, (2) 15% of all data points (5 testing set) to determine when to stop training and optimizing of the network architecture, and (3) 15% of all data points (5 validation set) to test the generalization ability of the model.
Herein, the simulation results of the ANN fitting tool for predicting of MG and RhB adsorption on the prepared nanocomposite were presented. Fig. 12 shows the ANN architecture and Fig. 13 depicts the ANN
Fig. 13. The Network architecture.
Fig. 14. The relative error deviation between the actual and predicted data (a) MG and (b) RhB.
structure. It can be seen in Figs. 12 and 13, input layer includes dosage of adsorbent (g), Concentration of dye (mg/L), pH, and time (min). Hidden layer includes 10 neuron and output layer contains one neuron, which is removal percentage of dye from aqueous solution.
The value of R2, %AARD, and RMSE for train, validation and test and overall data are presented in Table S7. The data show that the model is robust for predicting actual adsorption data due to the high values of R2 and low values of %AARD and RMSE. The %AARD and RMSE can be measured by the equations:

Where Pred (k), Actual (i) and N are the predicted adsorption data values, the experimental density data and the number of data points, respectively.
Fig. 14 indicates the relative error deviation between the actual and predicted data for dyes, which includes relative deviation of the predicted values versus true data points. Well-distribution of data points around the zero deviation line shows that the high capability of model in estimation of true values. The error histogram for both dyes is shown in Fig. 15 to study further authentication of network performance. Fig. 16 represents the predicted values of ANN model and actual data for the MG and RhB adsorption. Due to high exactness of model, the predicted values followed the true data trend and lead to high agreement between true and outcome values of proposed model. Fig. 17 indicates the experimental data and the predicted ones versus the index of data points to train, validation and test, respectively. Due to an agreement between the experimental values and the estimated adsorption ones, the outputs of ANN model well overlapped by the experimental data.

sections.heading: 3.2.6. Adsorption isotherm studies
sections.text:
Many isotherm models study the mathematical relation between the number of removed pollutants by the adsorbent and equilibrium solution concentration. In this work, the adsorption isotherm experiments were conducted with 0.004 g of adsorbent and the dye concentration ranging from 10 to 40mg/L at optimum pH=6 and analyzed by the Temkin, Langmuir, Freundlich, and Elovich isotherm models (Table S8).
Four isotherm models were used to study the equilibrium data and adsorbate-adsorbent interaction at optimum conditions (pH=6, adsorbent= 0.004 g, contact time: 145min and dye= 10–40mg/L). The isotherm models were plotted (Fig. S1 for MG and Fig. S2 for RhB: Supplementary file). The isotherms constants for dye removal were presented in Table S9. The correlation coefficient (R2) values for pollutant adsorption by ZIF-8 and NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 indicated that isotherm data followed the Freundlich model, demonstrating the heterogeneity of the adsorbent surface. The values of n for the Freundlich isotherm for ZIF-8 and NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 indicated the favorable nature of adsorption. Also, the D–R isotherm data presented the physical nature of dye removal (E < 8 kJ/mol).

sections.heading: 3.2.7. Kinetic model studies
sections.text:
In an attempt to study the dyes removal rates by the MOFs, the pseudo-first order, pseudo-second order, intraparticle diffusion and the Elovich kinetic models are used to analyze the experimental data (Table S10). The kinetic models were plotted (Fig. S3 for MG and Fig. S4 for
RhB: Supplementary file). The kinetic constants were measured and presented in Table S11. The data followed the pseudo-second order model. The comparison of rate constants showed that the MOF removed dyes swifter than that of NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8.

sections.heading: 3.2.8. The evaluation of adsorbents
sections.text: Fig. 18 and Table 1 show dye removal percentage of the synthesized adsorbents at optimum condition of the experiment (pH=6, dye= 25mg/L, adsorbent= 0.004 g and time= 145min) and the results showed that encapsulation of NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 by ZIF-8 was successful. Dye removal of composites were more than CNTs and ZIF-8 individually.

sections.heading: 3.2.9. Mechanism of adsorption
sections.text: In this study, the strong electrostatic attraction between the cationic dyes molecules and negative surface charge of ZIF-8 and the π-π interaction between benzene rings of dyes molecules and organic ligand of ZIF-8 lead to high adsorption capacity of synthesized nanocomposite [47].

sections.heading: 3.2.10. Desorption and reuse studies
sections.text: The reusability is an important parameter, especially for industrial applications. In this work, the reusability of the synthesized NH2-CNT/ Fe2O3/ZIF-8 was compared with ZIF-8 by repeating the adsorption process for five times. In each cycle, the dye concentration was 25mg/ L, and 0.004 g of the nanocomposite was added and stirred for 145min. After each cycle, the separated materials were washed using ethanol. At last, the recovered adsorbents were washed and dried for 12 h at 60 °C then applied for another adsorption cycle. Fig. 19 indicates removal percentage of the MOF and nanocomposite. The nanocomposite exhibited stable and high reusability almost 91% efficiency over five cycles.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
Herein, NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8: NCFZ nanocomposites with different amounts of NH2-CNT/Fe2O3 (5, 10 and 15wt% denoted as NCFZ5, NCFZ-10, and NCFZ-15) were synthesized. The nanomaterials including ZIF-8, Fe2O3, CNT/Fe2O3, NH2-CNT/Fe2O3, CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8, NCFZ-5, NCFZ-10, and NCFZ-15 were characterized. They were used for selective removing MG and RhB from binary systems. Data are analyzed by several methods such as SPSS (Statistical Package for the Social Sciences) [67], Student t-test [68], etc. Herein, RSM and ANN were used for optimizing dye removal. The BET data showed that the surface area increased in nanocomposite (NH2-CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8: 1659m2/g) than that of pure (ZIF-8: 1485m2/g). Contaminant removal obeyed the
Freundlich isotherm and pseudo-second order kinetic models. The selected optimum amount of MG and RhB removal percentage in a binary mixture at an initial pollutant concentration of 25mg/L, pH of 6, NH2CNT/Fe2O3/ZIF-8 and mixing time of 0.004 g at 145min were 90.93 and 19.38%, respectively. The RSM presented optimum conditions experimentally were checked by running off 10 proposed runs and the same results achieved by < 2% errors. The outputs of ANN model overlapped with the experimental data. The binary system dye removal data indicated the synthesized nanocomposite with recycling and regeneration ability could be used for treating wastewater.
